This game was pretty cool at first.  I like the exploring, mining and building.  But the game doesn't really explain how you do anything and imo has some severe techincal limitations.  For example, I started a dedicated server with a friend who ended up in a completely different solar system from where i started.  I could still beam to them which worked but then I couldn't get back to the house we built with all of our stuff unless they were logged on or I built a flag to bookmark it.

So I built the flag.  Cool, problem solved.  Then I moved the flag to the upstairs of the house.  Figured i'd have to recreate the bookmark, which I did.  Got killed by a monster (you die A LOT in this game mostly due to being forced onto a keyboard or play with TERRIBLE controller support).  Back on the ship, I noticed there were now two bookmarks for the house.  I deleted one and teleported to the remaining one. I respawned on the ship and now both bookmarks are gone.  No way to get to the house unless my friend is on.  No feul to fly to their system.  Not good enough gear yet to get fuel.  So, I have to start from scratch or wait for them to logon.  1/10.  Garbage.

185757276.review:
Game is space terraria essentially, it isn't optimized and there are memory leaks from certain things like the pixel printer.

That being said, there's some mods to correct a few of those bugs as best possible.

I'd suggest not getting into the Frackin Universe overhaul, it changes way too much and adds a number of complicated (to lengthen the game and increase the grind) systems to the crafting and building parts of the game. At least not getting into it for a long while.

There's rumours of a console port of Starbound at some point in the future, and a number of those bugs and memory leaks would need to be patched before that.

As for mods you should really consider, even on a first playthrough: Frackin Universe + A.V.I.A.N. That whacky computer just adds so much personality to the game.

185643559.review:
Facilmente riassumibile in [b]DELUSIONE PROCEDURALE[/b].

Il gioco presenta e promette una serie di concetti interessanti, ma non riesce ad arrivare a fondo su nessuno di essi.

Starbound è un sandbox procedurale in 2D, con elementi di platforming e RPG, ma delude sotto ogni aspetto.
 
Il concetto di poter esplorare infiniti mondi, con la promessa di trovare una moltitudine enorme di variabili mostra i suoi limiti dopo le prime ore di gioco. I vari mondi, proceduralmente generati, sono quasi identici. Posso cambiare vagamente i colori, alcune decorazioni, ma finisce là. Una volta conosciuta quella tipologia di mondo, si perde subito l'elemento di novità. I nemici, anche se dall'aspetto diversi, sono tutti identici nelle dinamiche. Stessa IA, stessi attacchi e stessi pattern, facili da individuare, ma difficili da gestire per via dei comandi di gioco (altamente legnosi). 

Il gioco ha una storia principale e delle side quest che si possono svolgere, tuttavia è facile stancarsi. La storia principale sembra scritta da un bambino di 10 anni, mentre le side quest sono un eterno ripetersi di "oh ciao, mi porti quello?", "mi uccidi quell'altro?" In un ripetersi procedurale di cose IDENTICHE da fare, sia per quanto riguarda gli npc "random", che gli npc "principali". Si tratta sempre di esplorare gli stessi posti, per trovare le stesse cose, in modo sempre noioso. 
A proposito di npc: noiosi, ripetitivi, senza niente di interessare da raccontare. Alcuni sembrano le caricature di personaggi di altri giochi, altri sembrano l'ombra di chi avrebbero voluto essere da grandi. 

L'esplorazione è monotona, perché si ritrovano ancora e ancora gli stessi elementi. Scavare è tedioso, i drop non valgono mai il tempo speso, le chest sono piene di schifezze che il giocatore smette di usare dopo i primi 60 minuti di gioco, perché esistono alternative migliori. Morire è facile, e punitivo. Costruire una colonia, richiede uno sforzo immane per accumulare le stronzate che servono a creare degli edifici, e le risorse sono ben lontane dall'essere le une vicine alle altre. 

La grafica è carina, e lo stile è sicuramente interessante. La colonna sonora è la parte migliore di tutto il gioco. Il concept è accattivante, e per le prime ore di gioco sembra che parte della frustrazione derivi dall'inesperienza del giocatore, ma poi ci si accorge che è impossibile adattarsi a certe meccaniche, o divertirsi ripetendo quelle che diventano le stesse quest. 

Ci sono una serie di razze che si possono scegliere all'inizio del gioco, ma a parte l'aspetto estetico non fa alcuna differenza se decidi di giocare una scimmia di merda, un umano, o un uccello. Zero perk, zero fantasia. 

La gestione dell'inventario e l'hotbar per la selezione degli oggetti sono le cose più merdose che ho visto in 30 anni di carriera di gaming; dei veri aborti. 

Potrei continuare, ma mi fermo qui.

Le 103 ore di delusione accumulate su questo gioco sono dovute ai miei vari tentativi di farmelo piacere/ricominciarlo a più riprese, ma non ho mai finito un playthrough.
E se mi chiedete perché sono arrivato a 103 ore di gioco la risposta è questa: [b]"avete presente quando uscite e avete voglia di sushi, pizza, cocktail, ecc? Vi sedete: il piatto è una merda, il drink è una cagata, ma lo mangiate/bevete tutto lo stesso. Perché? avevate quella voglia specifica, non volevate fare problemi, avevate fame, avevate sete...ma sempre di merda siete stati."[/b]

185209954.review:
Starbound is like if you had a childhood friend you treasured since the day you met, only for the friendship to dwindle as said friend burns out and gets a lobotomy before ultimately ghosting you.

In its early development it had so much more to it, more world and biome types, more weapons and ambiguity in its universe, more bosses as well that you can find pieces of in the final build that don't do anything. The developers decided to gut a ton of content for the "Complete" version of the game while adding the most uninspired "Save the universe from a space racist" plotline. After years of silence, they added a very mid update of cyberpolice bounty hunting before ghosting the game excluding console ports. They're also abusive to their fan community, even going so far as to attempting to incorporate an alien species mod into the game as their own property with no compensation to its creator if they agreed to it.

The game plays decently, but there's barely any meat or potatoes to the game without the help of mods from its community, and after the disappointing main story there's not a lot to do outside of base creating and endlessly generated quests from settlements. 

If you still want to try Starbound, make sure to get it on sale as it is not worth its full price, and make sure to mod the game as its default gameplay depth is as shallow as a kiddie pool. Even though this game was the main reason I made a steam account I cannot recommend it with a clear consciousness.

Bad game. Thought it would be another Terraria, but no.

Building bases isn't worth it. You have to move to randomly generated planets for main quest and to gather better resources. Basically, for each planet, you have to restart digging a mine, setting up a camp with crates and a flag.

You can expand and build your ship, but you need upgrade modules, all found as random loot of random planets. 

Deaths are very punishing on normal difficulty because you drop items.

Combat is very buggy and unsatisfying.
Guns use stamina for some reason.

Oh.. and main quest is very generic. It just is a generic "fetch and return" quest straight from Skyrim.

The only thing I enjoyed was cooking meals.

I enjoy using it for creative products and its a very chilled out, go to game for me even if it has so many issues.

This game has so many performance issues that not even modding can fix- every month I discover a new very commonly acknowledged bug that just remains unfixed by the devs. It is common knowledge this game was released unfinished and 
 with community-made unpaid content included. The devs were really shitty about the whole thing and do not deserve support. If you don't know please look it up for details on this.

Many bugs straight-up corrupt files and the only way to stop this is to regularly, manually back up and replace said corrupted files from backups otherwise there's a high chance you loose your entire Universe. The game is also just built poorly- it runs laggy as hell even when PC specs are well above recommendation and crashes often loading time also takes ages. There are Mods that can help performance but not fix it entirely.

If this game worked and all the features promised were out and it was properly balanced I'd recommend it but that's unlikely to happen so I won't. For a new player, it's not worth picking up and there are better options that are far less frustrating.

I do recognise the irony of this review with my hours, all I can say is leave me and my comfort pile of shit alone. The game is bad but I have a problem.

So Starbound, what is there to say that hasn't been said already? The game isn't super performance friendly, it had a rocky development, and Chucklefish hasn't really updated it in a while; but why do I like it? The short answer: mods; the long answer: mods provide this game a whole new lease on life (totally new campaigns, stories, etc... you can even remove the story if you want!), without them Starbound would, much like early No Man's Sky, be barely enjoyable after the first 20 hours. 

Should you buy Starbound? I'd say no, at least not at full retail price, get it on sale, mod it (a premade collection is your best bet, but give vanilla a try at least 10 hrs. And for your own sanity, consider avoiding Frackin Universe unless you want to deal with incompatibilities all the time or prefer a much slower progression system)

(Also FYI, you should check out OpenStarbound if you find performance issues with just the base game, it's a total engine rewrite that requires the core files from your install; though you can just as easily find most of the big mods either on the official forums or elsewhere)

184380817.review:
Playing Starbound felt like stepping into an endless universe of possibilities. At first, the game’s charming pixel art and vast procedural galaxy completely captivated me. I loved hopping from planet to planet, never knowing what kind of environment, creatures, or treasures I might encounter. The exploration was addictive, and the ability to shape and build my own bases gave me a real sense of ownership over my journey. The sci-fi aesthetic mixed with whimsical humor made the game feel unique, and the range of biomes and planets kept me curious about what else I might discover.

That said, after a while, the gameplay loop started to feel a bit repetitive. The procedural generation, while impressive, sometimes resulted in planets that felt more generic than distinct, and the quests often boiled down to fetch missions that lacked depth. The combat was serviceable, but it didn’t feel particularly tight or rewarding, and it sometimes got in the way of the exploration I enjoyed so much. Multiplayer was fun with friends, but the lack of a strong endgame or meaningful progression left me feeling like my adventures eventually ran out of purpose.

Still, Starbound was a relaxing and creative experience that scratched my itch for exploration and building. It may not have the staying power of some other sandbox games, but its charm, freedom, and sheer scope make it a game I’d revisit whenever I just want to wander the stars and see what’s out there.

Personally I felt like the game was a great successor to terraria, dare i say even better. While the reception has been overall strong, I think there is a lot left under the table as the game seems criminally underrated in my opinion.

184285018.review:
Starbound is an excellent game in the survival-crafting genre, with a little more direction than many.

(You are, of course, still free to largely ignore that direction, but as quest advancement unlocks some new features, it's worth knocking off at least the first few quests before going out to do your own thing. But for people who dislike endless aimless wandering and prefer to have stated goals, the game provides some to you.)

+ Music is great, appealing but still ambient enough to not get tiresome after many dozens of hours on repeat.

+ Graphics likewise strike a nice balance between being smooth and simple without being too pixelated to tell what things are.

+ A vast wealth of crafting options and upgrades, as you'd expect in a survival crafting game, and also some rarer upgrades for your movement abilities and your multipurpose mining tool "Matter Manipulator" which do everything from increasing range/speed/area to letting you mine water and recolor things.

+ Matter manipulator is unloseable and unbreakable, so even on drop-everything-on-death mode, you never have to worry about trapping yourself in a position where you can't grab whatever materials you need.

+ Wide variety of planets to explore with their own biomes and weird freaky creatures, trees, and NPCs. 

+ You get a giant mech that you can upgrade


= Multiplayer is finally functional on Steam so you can just invite friends without being a tech wizard


- Combat is "fine I guess", not great but not terrible

- Story campaign is not super-compelling, and there's more fun to be had in exploring random anomalies and the like than in trying to scan a dozen artifacts from whatever the next civilization is.


All in all, a compelling game that's easy to get lost in and lose track of time. Definitely worth your while, doubly so when it's on a super-sale for $5 like right now.

184015942.review:
While I did love this game, it's not without it's flaws. Let me explain the pros and cons respectively and I'll get depth on why I feel the way I do.

Pros:
-Large variety of blocks, resources, crafting and building
-Inter-planetary travel
-Worlds loop around
-Worlds have their own major and sub biomes
-Rich lore and many playable races
-Advanced modding community
-Wide roster of weapons
-Selectable difficulty levels
-Customize your own space ship and pilot your mech
-Build a crew or develop a colony
-Lots of exploration to do
-Lovely soundtrack
-Cozy pixel art style
-Enemies won't track you unless you go close
-You can duel wield
-Encounter structures and villages
-Special abilities to augment your movement
-Ways for farming and automation 
-More content than you know what to do with

Cons:
-Overwhelmingly reliant on mods
-Clunky Combat
-World weather and enemies can grief
-Extremely limited viable usage of mechs
-Crafting vs exploring progression at odds
-Planets become redundant
-No variation of underground structures or layouts
-NPC's that aren't merchants painfully bland and useless
-Crew members are brainless bullet sponges who stand in everyone's way. Even yours.
-Trying to read the lore is punishing to the player, the game does not pause when reading and hunger ticks down
-The story and progression is messy, and mods have no real answer
-Difficulty seesaws between too hard and too easy, and NPC quests do not scale to the the planet's threat level
-90% of loot is weapons. You'll have too many weapons and none strong enough for what you actually need to face
-You have to dedicate the game's accessory slot to an item called "EPP" in order to survive a planet for more than a minute.
-Boss loot is often underwhelming, and enemy loot is 90% low-tier crafting resources
-No minimap to track where you are or where you've been
-Sub menus like inventory and codex do not pause the game even if you play singleplayer
-No real to stifle enemy spawns for safe building, or increase them for combat
-Quest markers are often inaccurate and unreliable


I loved this game at first, got addicted even. While this game does have a lot of content, it doesn't have depth. Colony building, trading, events, missions, but they all feel very surface level. While it's easy to get caught up in the glitz and glamour of a new race mod, new weapon set, or a new planet, but that can only go so far. I kept getting sobered by the fact that these planets have nothing new but recolored rock and soil, I need a new EPP to survive on the planet, and encountering a village of the new race mod I installed only gives me 1 line quotes and the same awful quests I can get anywhere. I thought I try my hand in colony building, only to realize they don't have any of the charm or utility of minecraft's villagers or terraria's town NPC's. The one time you find a mission, structure or enemy encounter that's exactly to the level of your gear and weaponry, the fun ends the moment you realize enemies don't respawn/have a spawner to come back from and the moment is all gone once you deal with all the enemies. Even with mods, I do not reccommend starbound, it can't scratch the itch you're hoping it can get.

183649102.review:
特别喜欢的一款游戏
形式和画风有点像泰拉瑞亚，不过真的有非常多自己的内容，是太空主题的星际探险。玩家在不同的星球穿梭，探索不同的地貌和生命体。建造、战斗、采矿、种地、用精灵球捕捉小怪物（OMG!!!）、升级飞船和机甲，通过丰富的主线任务和支线任务来探索和了解这个宇宙的世界观。
好喜欢飞船在宇宙里穿梭然后靠近星球的动画😭有种「永恒和一瞬」的美感……
好喜欢不同的星球都有自己特别美丽的地方，还有吓人的地方！在海洋里、陆地上、大气之中都有身临其境的感受，和朋友玩很有趣，自己玩也不觉得孤独，光是探索生物和挖矿就让我沉迷了🥺
还喜欢酣畅淋漓的战斗！昨天我还是一个不知道副本是啥意思的人，今天我就是一个跟朋友约着刷副本的人了！我好开心！我好厉害！
这个游戏真的结合了所有我喜欢的点！想休闲就种种地探索星球、想刺激就挑战副本打怪、想收集就捕捉精灵（OMG!!），乐趣似乎和宇宙一样无穷无尽！

缺点：
1. 无官方中文，需要打汉化补丁。
2. 服务器不稳定，朋友的存档崩溃过三次……联机卡顿，有时候地图太大，电脑不好直接卡死。
3.存在一些不太合理的设计，比如储物空间太少，但是可以通过mod优化游戏体验

浏览starbound创意工坊真的要笑死，最热门之一的mod是“dramatic death”，将死亡动画变得更加炫酷，“make the act of dying and killing more impactful" 人化身光影在空中旋转一圈才华丽死亡。
还有一个好笑的，这个游戏的制作商叫chucklefish，中文翻译是呵呵鱼，刚打开游戏的时候会显示LOGO，是一个圆球形的鱼，它会笑一下并且伴有giggle的音效，然后我看到有人专门做了个mod把这个音效去掉。。。。哈哈哈哈哈啊啊啊啊啊

我在炎热星球用冰块造房子 然后下火雨了 把我冰块房顶全烧穿了 笑死啊
我告诉朋友这件事说好严谨啊 朋友说可是我之前身上着火了然后掉水里还是不会灭火 严谨了但是没那么严谨
好吧 不用冰块改成别的了 结果开始下陨石了把我房顶家具全砸了

朋友跟我一起玩，她选角色的时候没注意看内裤的颜色，但是角色睡觉的时候会自动变成半裸，于是她发现她选的角色内裤是绿色的、、、、妈呀笑死了啊啊啊，她崩溃了说她绝对不允许她的角色是绿色内裤，“你想象一下，我这么英俊帅气，穿着超酷胸甲，xxoo的时候一脱裤子内裤是绿的， 不能接受！！”
于是她想尽一切办法修改自己的内裤颜色，可是初始设定已经定了，游戏里没法更改，她去搜了有没有改变内裤颜色的mod，没有，啊啊啊啊啊只有不穿内裤的mod！！我笑死了，她说宁可打这个不穿内裤的mod也不要绿色内裤。
于是她就这个绿色内裤搞了好久，最后甚至下了存档修改器把内裤颜色改了。。。。笑死我了，改完之后她太高兴了，现在她不穿衣服只穿内裤在地图上晃荡了。。。

很棒的一点是，除了人类种族，我在其他种族身上真的感觉不到明显的性别差异。它们也会梳小辫，留长发短发，穿亮丽的衣服，有着粗粗的或者甜美的声线，但是不会让人觉得「这是女的」或者「这是男的」。因此我感觉很舒服，我选择成为叶族人，那我就是头戴小花冠的叶族人，不是「叶族女人」，只要开心地在这个宇宙驰骋就好了。

还有 最喜欢starbound可以靠偷鸡摸狗发家致富！！！喜欢npc家里的漂亮家具，偷！需要钱和道具装备，偷！懒得自己做冰箱微波炉，偷偷偷！最喜欢去npc城镇翻箱倒柜……我所到之地寸草不生！

183644492.review:
Nobody reads my reviews anyway.
I'll throw in a recipe for Varenyky.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

183608354.review:
Starbound é um jogo que eu vejo sendo muito comparado ao Terraria, mas sinceramente eu acho muito nada a ver essa comparação já que a jogabilidade de ambos é completamente diferente. O jogo tem muitas coisas divertidas como um universo infinito que você pode explorar, o problema desse aspecto entra quando você já explorou cada tipo de estrela algumas vezes, já que começa a ficar meio repetitivo já que cada espécie possui umas 2 estruturas cujo você pode encontrar (o que somaria aproximadamente em umas 8 ou 10 estruturas diferentes encontráveis), então você começa a encontrar muita repetição pelos planetas, já que além das estruturas criadas por gente existem as estruturas do planeta cujo podem fazer ele se repetir mais ainda.
 No quesito de combate, o jogo não peca muito contra inimigos comuns já que você não deveria ter tanto trabalho quando o assunto é lidar com poucos inimigos, a dificuldade nesse aspecto só vem quando o jogo lança muitos inimigos de uma vez, mas ainda assim nada demais. Contra bosses eu sinceramente sinto que eles são meio 'simplera' demais, (vou comparar o jogo a Terraria um pouco agora) jogando Terraria pela primeira vez sempre que eu enfrentava um boss novo parecia um experiência diferente e divertida, contra os bosses de Starbound eu entrava no boss, tomava alguns hits e depois já entendia o moveset o suficiente pra não morrer uma singular vez na luta, já que cada boss tinha poucas diferenças de ataques, além dos ataques serem muito simples. Por exemplo, um boss cujo curti muito e fiquei meio triste que não houveram mais bosses com mecânicas interessantes igual a ele foi o primeiro boss do jogo, uma criatura que fica no centro da arena e você tem que ativar consoles próximos para causar dano, que por mais que seja uma mecânica simples, realmente diferencia ele do resto dos bosses, já que a maioria deles se resume a esperar o boss aquietar pra você conseguir bater nele sem ser brutalmente morto (alias alguns deles nem é necessário você tomar cuidado para não morrer já que ele mal consegue fazer nada contra você). Alguns bosses parecem terem sido feitos fáceis demais e outros quase tiveram uma dificuldade boa mas adicionaram algum fator desnecessário (como o dragão de ossos cujo NÃO precisava invocar cultistas para te bater junto dele, já que o fogo no chão já atrapalhava o suficiente a lutar contra ele).
 Os itens eu também senti uma tristeza na hora de consegui-los, já que minerar nesse jogo é uma tristeza, pois você precisa descender bastante nos planetas para conseguir bastante minério, mas se você descer muito você não pode teletransportar e é obrigado a voltar a pé (cujo pode levá-lo a morte e consequentemente a perder os minérios coletados caso você esteja na segunda dificuldade como eu). Além disso quando o assunto eram armas eu percebi bastante que as armas que você constrói não são nem perto de forte quando comparado as armas encontradas em missões, bosses e coisas semelhantes (eu mesmo desisti muito rápido de craftar armas e passei a usar armas que me foram dadas pelo resto do jogo.
 Os planetas no geral não apresentam tanta dificuldade, com exceção de um cujo eu tive especial dificuldade em fazer qualquer coisa, esse sendo os planetas vulcânicos, já que a chuva de fogo atrapalha a movimentação, a lava te mata rapidamente se você não tomar cuidado e por fim, os meteoros. Os meteoros quebram blocos e te dão hit kill (pelo menos pra mim eu sempre levei hit kill).
 Por fim em considerações finais, o sistema de fome é algo desnecessário que só serve como uma inconveniência leve que pode se tornar um problema caso você se esqueça dela e não colete muita comida pelo jogo.
 No geral o jogo não é RUIM, mas poderia certamente muito melhor com alguns update para deixar mais interessante, portanto vou tentar uma jogatina com mods e possivelmente editarei essa analise com uma sessão extra falando sobre os mods.
